text:
Opening Question

Explain a problem you solved or how someone solved a problem for you.

Learning about Water Conservation

Watch this video from National Geographic explaining why water is important, and why and how we should conserve water.

Whole-class discussion

“Why is water conservation important?”

Discuss this question with your group then record your reflections and questions in your workspace. Use your sharing and group tools to view each other's responses and discuss with your teammates.

Engineering Ideation

Engineers have always used freeform sketching as a way to help generate new solutions to problems. Leonardo DaVinci kept hundreds of pages of notebooks on every kind of idea.

tiles.title: A page from Leonardo's Notebook on Water Moving devices

text:
Introducing a Problem Statement

What are some ways we can save water in our school?

  1. Write up a list of 10 ideas.
  2. Sketch at least 3.

What do we need to do next if we want to work on this problem?

Community Connection

Take a quiet walk around the school with a notebook. Note any community members (e.g., stakeholders — office staff, custodians, students from other grades). With teacher support, you may ask community members what they think about water conservation.

Engineer Notebook

Explain why water conservation is important to me (or my community). Note anything important you learned, any questions you have, any design ideas/sketches or whatever else you want to write about!

Opening Questions

Why is water conservation important? (Review)

Who should conserve water? List three kinds of people in your community that should conserve water.

Stakeholder Mapping

Whole-class activity: Review your problem statement and create a list of stakeholders. Drag this starter card deck into your workspace, and add your stakeholders. Use these cards to sort in different ways.

Sort 1: Sort the group into at least 2 categories. You will need to add more categories to the sample deck. Label each group consistently in the cards. Explain your categories to everyone in the class.

Sort 2: Now complete a second sort with at least two of the following categories: beneficiaries/consumers, resource providers, influential bystanders and potential allies. You can also add additional stakeholders to your card deck at this time.

Problem Statement Reframe

Debrief: How does mapping help us understand a problem and create a solution?

What changes should we make to our problem statement now that we understand stakeholders?

Engineer Notebook

Explain how your problem statement changed and why. Explain, note, or sketch anything else related to today’s class.

Community Connection (Optional)

Share your stakeholder map with one important person in your home. Note any thoughts they have on your stakeholder map.
